definition: Age of the subject when he/she was scanned.
Mean of the horizontal girths for both legs measured at the level of the outer ankle point.

Horizontal girth of the left leg measured at the level of the outer ankle point. Subject stands erect (tape). The outer ankle point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.18) is the most lateral point of the outer ankle bone (lateral malleolus).

Horizontal girth of the right leg measured at the level of the outer ankle point. Subject stands erect (tape). The outer ankle point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.18) is the most lateral point of the outer ankle bone (lateral malleolus).
A closed 3D mesh of triangles which defines a geometrical representation of a human body.
A closed 3D mesh of triangles which defines a geometrical representation of a human body.

Angle formed by the projection into the Ground plane of the line between 1st and 5th Metatarsal heads and the perpendicular of the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
Perimeter of the ball section, which is the section passing through 1st and 5th metatarsal heads and perpendicular to the ground plane.
Maximal height of the ball section, which is the section passing through 1st and 5th metatarsal heads and perpendicular to the ground plane.

Distance from the rearmost point of the foot to the intersection of the ball section and the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
Maximal distance between the extreme points of the ball section (section passing through 1st and 5th metatarsal heads and perpendicular to the ground plane) projected into the Ground plane.
Distance over the body across the back between back armpits at back armpit level. Subject stands erect (tape)

Vertical distance from back neck point to the ground. Subject standing and head in Frankfurt plane (anthropometer). The back neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.6) is the tip of the prominent bone at the base of the back neck in the mid-sagital plane, and projected posteriorly to the surface of the skin. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Center back waist length
definition: Distance from back neck point to waist level. Subject stands erect with shoulders relaxed and head in Frankfurt plane (tape). The back neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.6) is the tip of the prominent bone at the base of the back of the neck in the mid-sagital plane, and projected posteriorly to the surface of the skin. Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bone at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

Distance from back neck point following the contour of the spinal column to the hip level and vertical level of the centre point of knee-cap. Subject standing and head in Frankfurt plane (tape+anthropometer). The back neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.6) is the tip of the prominent bone at the base of the back neck in the mid-sagital plane, and projected posteriorly to the surface of the skin. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically. The centre point of the knee-cap (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.17) is the centre of the patella when the thigh muscles are relaxed.

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Accross back shoulder width
definition: Distance between the right and left shoulder points. Subject sits or stands erect with shoulders relaxed (tape). The shoulder point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.2) is the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin.
Body volume contained within the watertight mesh.
Horizontal girth measured at bust point level. Bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing a bra. Subject stands erect (tape)

Vertical distance from the bust point to the ground. Subject in standing and head in the Frankfurt plane (anthropometer). Bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing a bra. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 chest/bustpoint to bust point width
definition: Distance between the bust points. subject stands erect (tape). The bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing bra.
Vertical distance from the cervicale to a point level with a midpoint of the back of the knee (or crease).
Country where raw data was acquired. The Alpha-2 code in the ISO 3166-1 is selected to describe the countries.
Vertical distance from neck back level to hip level (anthropometer).
Mean of the girths of the left and right arms at the elbow point.

Girth of the left arm at the elbow point. Subject stands erect (tape). The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Girth of the right arm at the elbow point. Subject stands erect (tape). The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Distance between the rear- and foremost point of the foot projected into the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
A closed 3D mesh of triangles which defines a geometrical representation of a human foot.
Mean of the maximum circumferences of both forearms.
The maximum circumference of the left forearm, one-third of the distance from the olecranon to ulnar styloid (tape).
The maximum circumference of the right forearm, one-third of the distance from the olecranon to ulnar styloid (tape).

Vertical distance from front neck point to the ground. Subject standing and head in Frankfurt plane (anthropometer). The front neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.8) is the crossing point of the line connecting medial superior boarders of the left and right clavicles and front median line.
Distance over the body across the front between frontal armpits at frontal armpit level. Subject stands erect (tape)
Gender of the subject (either male or female).
Width of the heel at the height of the most prominent lateral point of heel section, located at 16% of foot length.

Maximum, approximately horizontal, girth of head measured above centre point of brow ridge and crossing the rearmost point of the head. Hair shall be included in the measurement (tape). Subject sits or stands erect with head in Frankfurt plane. The centre point of the brow ridge (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.2) is the most anterior point of the forehead between the brow ridges in the mid-sagital plane. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

Maximum horizontal distance across the hips. Subject stands erect, measure is taken without pressing into the flesh of the hips (large sliding calliper). Hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.25) is the level of the greatest prokection at the back of the body (buttocks) (large sliding calliper)

Horizontal girth of the body measured at the hip level. Hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.25) is the level of the greatest projection at the back of the body (buttocks). Subject stands erect with relaxed abdomen (tape)

Vertical distance from the hip level to the ground. Subject stands erect (anthropometer). The hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.25) is the level of the greatest projection at the back of the body (buttocks).

Perimeter of the Instep section, which is a perpendicular section to the foot axis located at 50% of foot length. Foot axis passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.

Maximal height of the instep section, which is a perpendicular section to the foot axis located at 50% of foot length. Foot axis passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
Perimeter of the section that passes through the heel to the Instep point, located at 50% of foot length.

Maximal width of the instep section, which is a perpendicular section to the foot axis located at 50% of foot length. Foot axis passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.

Vertical distance from the inside leg level to the ground. Subject in standing A position. The inside leg level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.26) is the level at the highest visible point at the junction between the right and left thighs observed from the back of subject (anthropometer)
Mean of the horizontal girths of both knees at the level of the centre point of knee-cap.
Horizontal girth of the left knee at the level of the centre point of knee-cap. Subject stands erect (tape).
Horizontal girth of the right knee at the level of the centre point of knee-cap. Subject stands erect (tape).

Mean of the vertical distances from the center point knee-cap of both knees to the ground. Subject standing (anthropometer). The centre point of the knee-cap (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.17) is the centre of the patella when the thigh muscles are relaxed.

Vertical distance from the center point knee-cap of the left knee to the ground. Subject in standing (anthropometer). The centre point of the knee-cap (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.17) is the centre of the patella when the thigh muscles are relaxed.

Vertical distance from the center point knee-cap of the right knee to the ground. Subject in standing (anthropometer). The centre point of the knee-cap (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.17) is the centre of the patella when the thigh muscles are relaxed.
Height of 5th Metatarsal head.

Distance from the left elbow point to the left wrist point. Subject stands erect (tape). The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist). The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna.

Distance from the right elbow point to the right wrist point. Subject stands erect (tape). The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist). The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna.

Distance from the elbow point to the wrist point. Subject stands erect (tape). The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist). The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna.
Height of 1st Metatarsal head.

Vertical distance from the level of the maximum hip girth to the ground. Subject stands erect (anthropometer). The maximum hip girth (ISO 8559-1:2017 5.3.14) is the maximum horizontal girth of the body below the hip level. The hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.25) is the level of the greatest projection at the back of the body (buttocks).
Mean of both minimum horizontal girths of lower legs just above the ankle bones.
Minimum horizontal girth of the lower left leg just above the ankle bone. Subject stands erect (tape).
Minimum horizontal girth of the lower right leg just above the ankle bone. Subject stands erect (tape).
Height of the Navicular point.

Distance from the rearmost point of the foot to the Navicular point projected into the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.

Girth of the neck at point just below the bulgue at the thyroid cartilage and measured perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the neck (tape). Subject sits or stands with head in Frankfurt plane. The point employed (also named Adam's apple point), is the most anterior point of the thyrois cartilage (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.9). The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.
Mean of the distances from the left and right side neck points, over the back, to the waist level. Subject stands erect (tape)

designation: Neck shoulder point to waist left
definition: Distance from the left side neck point, over the back, to the waist level. Subject stands erect (tape)

designation: Neck shoulder point to waist right
definition: Distance from the right side neck point, over the back, to the waist level. Subject stands erect (tape)

Distance from shoulder point to wrist point (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Distance from left shoulder point to left wrist point (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Distance from right shoulder point to right wrist point (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Distance from the rearmost point of the foot to the 1st Metatarsal head projected into foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.

Distance from the rearmost point of the foot to the 5th Metatarsal head projected into the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.

Distance, measured vertically on the body from back neck point to the upper edge of a tape measure passing horizontally under the arms axilla. Subject stands erect and head in Frankfurt plane (tape). The back neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.6) is the tip of the prominent bone at the base of the back of the neck in the mid-sagital plane, and projected posteriorly to the surface of the skin.

Distance along a straight line from acromion to acromion. Subject stands erect with shoulders relaxed (large sliding caliper or large spreading caliper). The acromion point (ISO 7250-1:2017 5.2) is the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin.

Distance from the side neck point to the left shoulder point. Subject stands erect with shoulders relaxed (tape). The side neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.7) is the crossing point of the neck base line and the anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The neck base line (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.1) is the line at the neck base defined using a chainette that pases back neck point and the front neck point. The shoulder point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.2) is the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin.

Distance from the side neck point to the right shoulder point. Subject stands erect with shoulders relaxed (tape). The side neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.7) is the crossing point of the neck base line and the anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The neck base line (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.1) is the line at the neck base defined using a chainette that pases back neck point and the front neck point. The shoulder point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.2) is the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin.

designation: Side neck point to waist level
definition: Distance from side neck point, over the bust point, then vertically straight to the waist level. subject stands erect, shoulders relaxed and head in Frankfurt plane (tape). The bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing bra. Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bon    e at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

designation: Side neck point to waist level left
definition: Distance from left side neck point, over the left bust point, then vertically straight to the waist level. subject stands erect, shoulders relaxed and head in Frankfurt plane (tape). The bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing bra. Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bon    e at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.

designation: Side neck point to waist level right
definition: Distance from right side neck point, over the right bust point, then vertically straight to the waist level. subject stands erect, shoulders relaxed and head in Frankfurt plane (tape). The bust point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most anterior point of the bust when wearing bra. Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bone at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.
Vertical distance from the highest point of the  head in the median line to the ground (stadiometer)

The angle formed by the projection on the ground plane of the line between T1-T5 and the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
Perimeter of the convex hull of the toes section, which is the section passing through 1st and 5th toe joints.
Maximal height of the toes section, which is the section passing through 1st and 5th toe joints.

Distance from the rearmost point of the foot to the intersection of the toes section and the foot axis, which passes through the projections in the ground plane of the rearmost point of the foot and the midpoint between the 1st and 5th metatarsal heads.
Maximal distance between the extreme points of the toes section (section passing through 1st and 5th toe joints) projected into the Ground plane.
Mean of the maximum horizontal girths of the thighs below the gluteal fold.
Maximum horizontal girth of the left thigh below the gluteal fold. Subject stands erect (tape).
Maximum horizontal girth of the right thigh below the gluteal fold. Subject stands erect (tape).

Horizontal girth of the body measured at the top hip level. Subject stands erect with abdomen relaxed (tape). Top hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.24) is the midway level between the waist level and hip level. The hip level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.25) is the level of the greatest projection at the back of the body (buttocks). Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bone at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Cervicale to crotch height
definition: Vertical distance from back neck point to the inside level. Subject standing and head in Frankfurt plane (anthropometer). The back neck point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.6) is the tip of the prominent bone at the base of the back neck in the mid-sagital plane, and projected posteriorly to the surface of the skin. The inside leg level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.26) is the level of highest visible point at the junction between the right and left thighs observed from the back of the subject. The Frankfurt plane (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.2.5) is the standard horizontal plane at the level of the left tragion, upper border of the cartilaginous flap in front of the ear hole, and the left orbitale, the lower border of the orbital margin, when the mid-sagital plane of the head is held vertically.
Horizontal girth of the body at the under bust level. Subject stands erect (tape). The under bust level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.20) is the level directly below breast when wearing bra.
Mean of the left and right upper-arm girths.

Girth of the left upper arm measured midway between the shoulder point and elbow point (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Girth of the right upper arm measured midway between the shoulder point and elbow point (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Shoulder to elbow length
definition: Distance from the shoulder point to the elbow point. Subject stands erect (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Shoulder to elbow length
definition: Distance from the left shoulder point to the left elbow point. Subject stands erect (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Shoulder to elbow length
definition: Distance from the right shoulder point to the right elbow point. Subject stands erect (tape). Shoulder point is (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.1) the most lateral point of the lateral edge of the spine (acromial process) of the scapula, projected vertically to the surface of the skin. The elbow point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.11) is the most prominent point of the olecranon of ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).
Body volume contained within the watertight mesh.
Width of the waist girth. Subject stands erect (sliding caliper).
Frontal part of waist girth measurement. Subject stands erect (tape)

Horizontal girth of the body measured at the waist level. Subject stands erect with abdomen relaxed (tape). Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bone at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.

Vertical distance from the waist level to the ground (anthropometer). Subject standing and abdomen relaxed. Waist level (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.22) is the midway level between the lowest rib point and the highest point of the hip bone at the side of the body. Lowest rib point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.15) is the inferior point of the bottom of the rib cage (tenth rib) projected horizontally, 45 degrees from the midsagital plane, to the surface of the skin. The highest point of the hip bone (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.16) is the highest point at the side of the upper border of the iliac crest.

otherCompatibleStd: ASTM D5219-15 Waist to hip/seat height
definition: Vertical distance from waist level to buttock level. Subject stands erect (anthropometer)

source: ASTM D5219-15 Waist to knee height
definition: Vertical distance from the waist level to a point level with the midpoint of the back of the knee (or crease), taken plumb
Total weight of the body.
Mean of the girths of both wrists.

Girth of the left wrist at the level of the wrist point (tape). The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).

Girth of the right wrist at the level of the wrist point (tape). The wrist point (ISO 8559-1:2017 3.1.19) is the most prominent point of the bulge of the head of the ulna (prominent bone at the little finger side of the wrist).
